snippet.textDisplay:
This was our last video for the year 12019 of the Human Era. And what a year it was. So much stuff happened everywhere. To so many different people.
Calendars and holidays are just imaginary but they help us to cut our lives into pieces that our brains can handle.
We are leaving 12019 behind with a weird mixture of disillusion and hope. The world is screwed up. But we can fix it. In a few days this year will be over. And we all get to try again.
Thank you for watching our videos and for sticking around for so many years. See you all in 12020.
snippet.textOriginal:
This was our last video for the year 12019 of the Human Era. And what a year it was. So much stuff happened everywhere. To so many different people.
Calendars and holidays are just imaginary but they help us to cut our lives into pieces that our brains can handle.
We are leaving 12019 behind with a weird mixture of disillusion and hope. The world is screwed up. But we can fix it. In a few days this year will be over. And we all get to try again.
Thank you for watching our videos and for sticking around for so many years. See you all in 12020.

snippet.textDisplay: when undertaking a project of such proportions we need to keep in mind that just moving the sun like this wouldn't allow the solar system to simply follow along, every object in the solar system has both its orbit and its own momentum acting on it. To ensure this doesn't cause some planets, asteroids and other objects to fall out of their orbits there would need to be millions of calculations regarding when we apply thrust, how much thrust to apply and how to correct the orbits of anything that isn't perfectly positioned when other instances of thrust occur to ensure objects don't just start colliding with each other. We would of course be able to do these things, but to simply ignore it in this episode seems a little... off-putting. Rant over, still a great thought experiment and I did enjoy this episode. Perhaps in another episode an exploration into how we could move the Earth both into orbit to match our sun's expansion and into an entirely new solar system in preparation for its imminent collapse without disrupting things like the tides and other infrastructure we have for ourselves, and ideally without even messing with our temperature on the surface during an interstellar leap (perhaps geothermal would be sufficient if we took full advantage of it?) may make for an interesting episode
snippet.textOriginal: when undertaking a project of such proportions we need to keep in mind that just moving the sun like this wouldn't allow the solar system to simply follow along, every object in the solar system has both its orbit *and* its own momentum acting on it.  To ensure this doesn't cause some planets, asteroids and other objects to fall out of their orbits there would need to be millions of calculations regarding *when* we apply thrust, *how much* thrust to apply and *how* to correct the orbits of anything that isn't perfectly positioned when other instances of thrust occur to ensure objects don't just start colliding with each other.  We would of course be able to do these things, but to simply ignore it in this episode seems a little... off-putting.  Rant over, still a great thought experiment and I did enjoy this episode.  Perhaps in another episode an exploration into how we could move the Earth both into orbit to match our sun's expansion and into an entirely new solar system in preparation for its imminent collapse without disrupting things like the tides and other infrastructure we have for ourselves, and ideally without even messing with our temperature on the surface during an interstellar leap (perhaps geothermal would be sufficient if we took full advantage of it?) may make for an interesting episode

snippet.textDisplay:
Can someone explain me why we can ignore all the bodies in our solar system and just focus on the Sun ?
I mean ok, the Sun makes up 99.86% of the mass of our solar system, but still, why accelerating the Sun, let's say 20km/s in one direction would make all the planets follow it without any disturbances ? Shouldn't the new relative velocity between the Sun and the planets/other bodies should heavily modify de orbits of the said objects around the Sun ? After all, The engine is only tugging the Sun, and modifying the speed of the Sun relative to the Earth is the same thing as modifying the speed of Earth relative to the Sun, and the later would obviously affect Earth's orbit...


So it seems like a bold claim, and I can't find anything in the sources to back it up
snippet.textOriginal:
Can someone explain me why we can ignore all the bodies in our solar system and just focus on the Sun ?  
I mean ok, the Sun makes up 99.86% of the mass of our solar system, but still, why accelerating the Sun, let's say 20km/s in one direction would make all the planets follow it without any disturbances ? Shouldn't the new relative velocity between the Sun and the planets/other bodies should heavily modify de orbits of the said objects around the Sun ? After all, The engine is only tugging the Sun, and modifying the speed of the Sun relative to the Earth is the same thing as modifying the speed of Earth relative to the Sun, and the later would obviously affect Earth's orbit...


So it seems like a bold claim, and  I can't find anything in the sources to back it up

snippet.textDisplay: Something that makes me think... what if, now hear me out here, what if our life on Earth is the only form of life that requires liquid water, or anything that we need? What if there’s a planet out there with life that depends on different things than we do? Life forms evolve, and if there’s life off our planet, then what says it has to follow our rules? Maybe there’s life on a planet that developed on a planet closer to its star, or maybe farther away, maybe on a planet with no liquid water, who’s to say it physically can’t happen? We can’t look at humanity for everything, we go based on the laws of physics, but in space, and most definitely outside the observable universe, there’s stuff that defy those laws. Time moves in 1 direction, forward, but black holes and wormholes can defy that, matter makes up everything, but antimatter or dark-matter make up almost nothing, etc. so who’s to say alien life can’t live or develops without certain aspects that we need?
snippet.textOriginal: Something that makes me think... what if, now hear me out here, what if our life on Earth is the only form of life that requires liquid water, or anything that we need? What if there’s a planet out there with life that depends on different things than we do? Life forms evolve, and if there’s life off our planet, then what says it has to follow our rules? Maybe there’s life on a planet that developed on a planet closer to its star, or maybe farther away, maybe on a planet with no liquid water, who’s to say it physically can’t happen? We can’t look at humanity for everything, we go based on the laws of physics, but in space, and most definitely outside the observable universe, there’s stuff that defy those laws. Time moves in 1 direction, forward, but black holes and wormholes can defy that, matter makes up everything, but antimatter or dark-matter make up almost nothing, etc. so who’s to say alien life can’t live or develops without certain aspects that we need?

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi, the other day I saw a video where an astronaut in the space station removes a screw and this one falls down and hits the floor making a strong noise, another astronaut detaches a small mic from his clothes and this one slips from his fingers falling rapidly only to be captured half way to the ground with quick reflexes.
If the evidence suggests that gravity obviously can be turned on an off with a switch, how exactly can that translate to the theories of the universe and moving the entire solar system to another dimension.
You sound very sophisticated and knowledgeable I am sure you can explain.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi, the other day I saw a video where an astronaut in the space station removes a screw and this one falls down and hits the floor making a strong noise, another astronaut detaches a small mic from his clothes and this one slips from his fingers falling rapidly only to be captured half way to the ground with quick reflexes.
If the evidence suggests that gravity obviously can be turned on an off with a switch, how exactly can that translate to the theories of the universe and moving the entire solar system to another dimension.
You sound very sophisticated and knowledgeable I am sure you can explain.

snippet.textDisplay:
Am i the only one who find these Kurzgesagt videos impossible and too damn ambitious? I mean we don't have enough material on earth or any other planets on our solar system to cover the sun and if we do it will just melt by the extreme temperatures of the sun. And yet people find this amazing and thinks that this will happen one day. But one day this will be watched by people from the future and call this stupid like we make fun of flying cars that were supposed to be what we are using right now according to the 80's videos. Smh.

I find almost all of their videos impossible and stupid. Feeding the imaginations of these sheep people.

snippet.textDisplay: If you've got a Dyson swarm orbiting the sun, can't you just use that to generate a magnetic field to use the sun as a fusion torch? Niven thought you could do it with a ringworld; what's the advantage of the Caplan thruster? Faster exhaust equals less mass lost for thrust? Or does Niven's thruster just not work with the math?
snippet.textOriginal: If you've got a Dyson swarm orbiting the sun, can't you just use _that_ to generate a magnetic field to use the sun as a fusion torch?  Niven thought you could do it with a ringworld; what's the advantage of the Caplan thruster?  Faster exhaust equals less mass lost for thrust?  Or does Niven's thruster just not work with the math?

snippet.textDisplay: Wait, wouldn't this have a huge problem if we went in a direction other than the poles of the sun, like reversing the direction entirely, in that our orbits are only the way they are because we're essentially corkscrewing around the sun as it travels through the galaxy?
